To better study the 1° site conformations sampled by the viral envelope simulation, we applied k-means clustering to the PCA points of Figure 1 E. A visual inspection of cluster centroids corresponding to four representative 1° site conformations (shown in Figure S10) reveals that R292 and R371, two key residues known to interact with the sialic acid carboxylate group, are the most flexible. In contrast, the carboxylate-stabilizing R152 residue moves outward in only one of the four representative conformations. Other pocket-lining residues such as R118 and D151, which previous works suggest may play a role in the molecular mechanisms of oseltamivir resistance,
13 are also relatively flexible in the apo state.
